user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of add_session_cookie:
```c
static void
add_session_cookie (struct Session *session,
                    struct MHD_Response *response)
{
  char cstr[256];
  snprintf (cstr,
            sizeof (cstr),
            "%s=%s",
            COOKIE_NAME,
            session->sid);
  if (MHD_NO ==
      MHD_add_response_header (response,
                               MHD_HTTP_HEADER_SET_COOKIE,
                               cstr))
  {
    fprintf (stderr,
             "Failed to set session cookie header!\n");
  }
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
char cstr[256];
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation: the fragment only declares a local array char cstr[256] and the code uses snprintf with sizeof(cstr), not any of the <string.h> functions listed by MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17. snprintf enforces the provided buffer size and will not write beyond cstr (it may truncate). A violation would occur if code used functions from <string.h> such as strcpy/strcat/memcpy to copy session->sid or COOKIE_NAME into cstr without ensuring the destination bounds.
